course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Contemporary Hong Kong Society
course.description: A sociologically informed examination of Hong Kong society. Topics include social change, political, economic and gender inequalities, the movement for democracy, popular culture, identity, intimacy, and family life.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: A little bit overrated (depends on people)
reviews.comment_content:
There are a total of three parts in the course:

PART ONE:  SOCIAL CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT
PART TWO. SOCIAL AND POLITICAL INEQUALITIES
PART THREE. IDENTITY, INTIMACY AND FAMILY

There are three to four topics in each part. The topics are usually related to some of the social phenomenon and their explanation.

The topics covered are quite board, without much special focuses. In my opinion, it is not too good to cover that wide range content for a introductory sociology course. It feels like the course is just lots of theories and phenomenons crammed into a single thing. It is quite difficult for a beginner (like me) to handle such amount of content.

I have taken an introductory sociology course (it is about HK society too) from another institution before. It focused only a few theories and elaborated each in details with a case. Maybe I have an more like an engineer mindset so I would prefer more structured things lol.

BTW Is that a common thing in HKUST? COMP 3711H and COMP 3511 gave me the same feeling.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think it quite depends on the teaching style that you prefer. I don't really like his style of teaching although others may fine with such a style.

The professor releases powerpoints after the lectures. For me, it is quite hard to catch up the progress in the lectures especially in this online setting. I prefer doing some preparation before lecture time and write some notes on the slides.

Despite all of that, I believe the professor is a nice and passionate person. He tried quite hard to make the lectures interactive.
reviews.comment_grading:
Should be similar to (or a little bit better than) normal UST grading. I got a little bit below mean for midterm I and final and slightly above mean in midterm II. I guess I would be slightly below mean in the overall score and it is reasonable to have a B-. I answered a few questions in class but not many so I am not sure about my participation marks.

My score (and score stats of this class):
Midterm I (25%): 21/31 (Mean: 22.29, Median: 23, SD: 4.84)
Midterm II (25%): 27/30 (Mean: 24.3, Median: 25.75, SD: 4.82)
Final (50%): 21/32 (Mean: 22.03, Median: 23, SD: 5.62)
Participation (Bonus, max 3%): unknown
Overall: 72.2% => B-

However, it should be noted that it is not easy to be above mean unless you have some experience on this kind of sociology course (or you are a hok ba).
reviews.comment_workload:
It you skip the assigned readings, the workload is just attending the lectures and exams.

There is no attendance taking in the lectures. However, you need to answer the questions in order to earn bonus participation points. There are also interactive components in the lectures that you would be able to experience when watching videos (e.g. breakout room discussion, drawings).

You can predict the kind of questions that would appear after having one or two midterms. I think the ratio of conceptual question vs the factual questions is about 1:1. You have to recite quite a lot of details meanwhile understand the concepts well to get a high score. I personally did not prepare well and often forget the facts and concepts. You have to spend quite some time for revision if you would like to aim high.

reviews.author: forreal
reviews.title: Recommend!
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1: Social Change and Development
Part 2: Social and Political Inequalities
Part 3: Identity, Intimacy and Family

I find the course content quite interesting. The professor includes quite a lot of content from different sources about an issue, giving a more comprehensive overview.

It is also quite thought-provoking to me since some of the issues the Professor mentioned in class was unknown to me before. I would recommend taking this course if you are interested to know more about Hong Kong society.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Groves is passionate about what he's teaching so I enjoyed his class.

However, he tends to give his lecture slides after class. I recommend taking concise notes in class and combine them with the lecture slides afterwards or just watch the lecture videos provided later if you need that.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Grade Composition:
First Midterm Exam     25%   
Second Midterm Exam  25%
Final Exam. 50%

Midterm 1
Mean 71.90 (out of 100)           Mean 22.29(out of 31)
Median 74.19 (out of 100)        Median 23 (out of 31)
SD 15.62 (out of 100)               SD 4.84 (out of 31)

Midterm 2
Mean 81.01 (out of 100)           Mean 24.30(out of 30)
Median 85.83 (out of 100)        Median 25.75 (out of 30)
SD 16.05 (out of 100)               SD 4.82 (out of 30)

Final
Mean 68.84 (out of 100)           Mean 22.03(out of 32)
Median 71.88 (out of 100)        Median 23 (out of 32)
SD 17.55 (out of 100)               SD 5.62 (out of 32)

But pls remember that participation is VERY ESSENTIAL to your grade since there are extra credits for it. Answer questions in class will be helpful!

In general, grading is nice if you pay attention in class since some questions are set based on the in-class discussion. Exams are generally manageable if you read through his slides and remember the details.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is generally light for this semester since we didn't get to do the social service project due to the circumstances.

There were just 2 midterms and 1 final plus participation in class.

reviews.author: Troy
reviews.comment_content:
PART ONE:  SOCIAL CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT
PART TWO. SOCIAL AND POLITICAL INEQUALITIES
PART THREE. IDENTITY, CONSUMERISM AND FAMILY

reviews.author: WHNR
reviews.title: Zoom lesson: super recommend!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
As mentioned by others...
It is very useful and inspiring to learn sth about HK and historical things in a sociological way.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is super encouraging and friendly. He tried to engage all the students by raising questions that can be easily answered.
There are also some reading materials, and some can be 20 pages long. Be sure to read them through to prep you for the exam!
reviews.comment_grading:
RMB to answer questions!!!!!! This is super essential to getting a good grade!!!!! I am really honest about this. I have so far get only 2 A range for my Lang course and I thought I will never get another A but this course do!!!!! Please be hard-working and attentive in class then you'll be fine!

In the midterms and finals, there are around 30 questions with only 2-3 short questions (just answer in 1-2 sentence) and others being MCQ. The MCQ are not tricky. You just need to read through the ppt and reading materials then you will be able to get similar marks with mine. (I am really honest here)

They start counting participation after the add-drop period and I answer questions nearly in every lesson.

Both the midterms take 25% of the grade, while the final takes 50% and participation adds an extra 10% to your grade which is also the key to determine your grade as >80% of the class stay silent.

Midterm 1
Mean 71.90 (out of 100)           Mean 22.29(out of 31)
Median 74.19 (out of 100)        Median 23 (out of 31)
SD 15.62 (out of 100)               SD 4.84 (out of 31)

Midterm 2
Mean 81.01 (out of 100)           Mean 24.30(out of 30)
Median 85.83 (out of 100)        Median 25.75 (out of 30)
SD 16.05 (out of 100)               SD 4.82 (out of 30)

Final
Mean 68.84 (out of 100)           Mean 22.03(out of 32)
Median 71.88 (out of 100)        Median 23 (out of 32)
SD 17.55 (out of 100)               SD 5.62 (out of 32)

My score
Midterm1: 26/31
Midterm2: 28/30
Final: 29/32
Participation: 10/10
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Because of Covid-19, all the groupwork and volunteering are cancelled. So just 2 midterms + 1 final. Light workload.

reviews.author: Bambibibi
reviews.title: Interesting course: excellent teaching and good grades
reviews.comment_content:
Highly recommend haha^^
Thought-provoking and interesting contents
Really broaden my horizon
Encourage me to reflect on social issues
Easy to handle too
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is really nice and he teaches well
He delivered the concepts clearly and in an interesting way
but i am too shy to answer his questions during class hahaha 0.0
reviews.comment_grading:
As long as you do revision you can get a fairly high mark:)
If you are hardworking enough, very high marks can be guaranteed!! As the questions are quite easy to handle to be honest...
Remember to attend lessons and listen to what he said... some questions are based on discussions during class
Midterm1 : 24/31 (mean 22.29, sd 4.84)
Midterm2 : 29/30 (mean 24.30, sd 4.82)
Final: 30/32 (mean 22.03, sd 5.62)
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light and reasonable
Due to COVID-19, only two midterms and one final exam
The syllabus is reasonable. You have plenty of time to revise the materials.
The only troublesome thing is the reading... very long and they will be tested:(((

reviews.author: Chanel
reviews.title: Localæœ‰ç€æ•¸
reviews.comment_content: The content is about HK society so many content is around HK news and hot topics.  Local people definitely have some advantage.  However,  there are so many topics and each topic has many many ppt slides.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a kind person.  

He wants an interactive class so class participation is so important.  Answering questions frequently will leave him a good impression.

The notes don't have everything he said in class so you better attend the class.  He played video in class quite often.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 40%
Final 60%

Extra credit:
Class participation 3%
Volunteer project 7% (It is optional but Nearly everyone did it)

Statistics
Midterm:
Mean 71.28 (out of 100)
Median 73.68 (out of 100)
SD 14.34 (out of 100)

Final:
Mean 74.09 (out of 100)
Median 75.61 (out of 100)
SD 14.81 (out of 100)

For me, both midterm and final are above over 1 SD. Finally I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Each week you have 1 lengthy reading material.  Usually more than 20 pages.

Both midterm and final are in MC (around 30-40 questions) plus 2-3 one sentence short questions. The exam format is quite good, however, the revision content is not.  There are quite a lot of ppt slide need to revise.  Also, all reading material, video played in class will be examined.  Actually some exam questions are from reading material and video.

Final exam is cumulative but most of the questions covers the topic after midterm, around 3-4 questions are from topic before midterm.

The volunteer project is quite time consuming.  I am doing the low income family project.  It requires 1 evening for briefing session, 1 weekend for family visit and 1 weekend for service.  We are given a list of questions to ask in the family visit.  Our group also needs to plan the details of the service session.  After that, each group needs to submit a maximum 10 page report to summarise the interview in family visit and the service session.

reviews.author: skone
reviews.title: More understanding Hong Kong
reviews.comment_content: Mainly about Hong Kong social development, like income disparity, racial discrimination. Quite easy for local students. There's also a voluntary project in different topics to help the racial minority in Hong Kong.
reviews.comment_teaching: Interesting, there are many interaction between professor and us. But no cellphone and tablets can be used during the lesson as he encouraged us to write the notes.
reviews.comment_grading: midterm just passed mean and final just below mean. But finally I got B. Just I mentioned there's also a voluntary project which contained 7 bonus mark and I got 6 eventually. Participation marks are also counted during the lesson.
reviews.comment_workload: readings will be allocated in LMES and professor indeed asked about the passage in the lessons. Exam included readings and powerpoint. If attending well in lesson, actually didnt find any difficulty in finishing both exams

reviews.author: littlepear
reviews.title: Good grade CC
reviews.comment_content: Refer to others
reviews.comment_teaching: He clearly explained the concepts with numerous examples. On the ppt, he used different colors to indicate the keywords, which could give you some hints about the main ideas he wanted you to remember.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final grade = highest 2 quizzes (20% each) + final exam (60%)
Quiz 1: mean 23.21 SD 5.49
Quiz 2 mean 25.84 SD 5.20
Quiz 3: mean 24.74 SD 6.48
Final: mean 23.97 SD 5.99

My scores:
Quiz 1: 26/33
Quiz 2: 27/33
Quiz 3: 29/36
Final: 30.5/38

They would drop the lowest quiz score (in my case is Quiz 1)
My overall score would be around 80% and my final grade is A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light. Although there are some assigned readings, he would list out the questions that you need to look for answers from the reading. That means you can simply disregard the remaining sections that will not be tested.

The quizzes/finals were mostly MCQs with one or two short questions. You don't need to worry about spelling because you can answer the short question in your own words. Although he stated that you do not need to memorize the dates, there will be 1-2 MCQ asking you which decade the specific event occurred.

If you want to get A range, you should pay more attentions to the details on the slides and readings (only focus on the assigned questions).

reviews.author: bbcab
reviews.title: Recommend
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1: Social Change and Development
Part 2: Social and Political Inequalities
Part 3: Identity, Intimacy and Family
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good. I think the topics are interesting and Professor explained them well.
He used simple wordings and his English is very clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair Grade
Canvas quizzes            40%
Final exam                   40%
Assignment                  20%

3 open book canvas quizzes. Only count the highest 2 quizzes.
Final exam close book.
All MC with 1-2 short answered questions.

My score:
Canvas quizzes:
Quiz 1 18/28 Mean: 20.13 (dropped lowest score)
Quiz 2 26/30 Mean: 24.4
Quiz 3 33/38 Mean: 30.48
Final exam 26/32 Mean: 20.4
Assignment 5/5 Mean: 4.4
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Light
1. Watch lecture videos. They are short and easy to understand but make sure you understand each page.
2. Readings every week. Just focus on the questions Professor provided. Skip all the irrelevant parts in the readings. They won't be tested.

reviews.author: é„­
reviews.comment_content: It is about hong kong's history, identity, politics, poverty, equality, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is purely online, watch video recorded by the teacher. There are some reading materials that are quite long for me.
reviews.comment_grading: I got above mean in all quizzes, a below mean in the group project, and got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Only have some quizzes, mostly mc, one or two short questions. It has around 20 questions each.  Around every two weeks a quiz on the campus on Saturday. One group assignment. It is about hong kong's identity or minority and etc. We need to record a video.

reviews.author: lolllll
reviews.comment_content:
PART 1:  Social Change & Development
PART 2. Social & Political Inequalities
PART 3. Identity, Intimacy & Family
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is self-paced learning mode in this semester. Prof. will upload around 3-6 videos every week and the videos are around 10 mins.
Prof. is quite nice and responds to questions on discussion board quickly.
He explains quite clearly and you can easily understand each topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes  75%
Projects  25%

5 quizzes in total but only count the highest 4 quizzes so you may skip 1 quiz.
The format is MCs with 1 short question.
It is conducted in Saturday due to self-paced learning mode.
reviews.comment_workload:
Watch all the videos, reading materials and documentary videos provided in the ppt. You may need to write down some notes.

There are questions for the reading materials so you do not need to read from the first page til the last page. You can simply find out the answers for each questions in the reading which is useful for the quizzes.

The project is creating a 6-8 mins video with 4-5 groupmates. You can form the group by yourself or let the TA randomly assign you to a group. There are 4 topics you can choose.

The quizzes are not difficult and very straight forward.

reviews.author: AdaLi
reviews.title: æœ‰æ“ºå¹¾å¤šå¿ƒæ©Ÿå°±æœ‰å’©grade
reviews.comment_content:
PART 1:  Social Change & Development
PART 2. Social & Political Inequalities
PART 3. Identity, Intimacy & Family
reviews.comment_teaching: Self-paced learning mode for this semester. Watch videos by your own at any time you like and you can ask any questions related to the lecture contents, quizzes, project,etc on Canvas Discussion. Prof usually will answer the question within 1 day. The videos are quite interesting with some documentary videos embedded in the teaching videos. At most 1 reading per week.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is quite good.

Quizzes  75%
Projects  25%

5 quizzes, almost all MC with 1 short question ( 1-sentence answer) for every quiz, conducted every 2 weeks in Saturday. Only count the highest 4 quizzes, so you can skip 1 quiz If you need to.
Quiz 1: 22/25 (mean: 18.15 SD:4.1ï¼‰
Quiz 2: 26/28 (mean: 21.9 SD:3.25)
Quiz 3: 25/27 (mean: 22.99 SD:3.79)
Quiz 4: 21/23 (mean: 16.03 SD:3.92ï¼‰
Quiz 5: 19/22 (mean: 16 SD: 2.94)

Project
4-5 students a group. You can form group by yourself or leave it to TA to form  group for you. 4 topic options in total. Each group need to make a 6-9 mins video to talk about your chosen topic. I think interviewing people is a key to perform better in the project because 3 out of 4 topics requires you to conduct interviews with specific group of people.
My group got full marks for the decided option (according to Canvas Grade record, full mark was set as 5 and the mean was around 4.15 for the chosen option of my group). TA did not announce the statistics for project video.
Best videos for each option are included as the scope for the last Quiz.

I got A+ at last.
reviews.comment_workload: Watch all the videos, readings and documentary videos and write some notes. In the teaching video, some keywords/concepts are shown in green. Those are very likely to be tested in quizzes. Pay attention to the questions about readings (stated in the beginning of teaching videos). Just look for the answers of those reading questions, no need to read the readings in detailed. Some reading questions appeared in the quizzes. Contents of documentary videos may also be tested, but is not very difficult. You should be able to choose the correct answers if you watched the documentary videos. Project video requires you to put some efforts if you want high grades, e.g. draft interview questions, video recording and editing.

reviews.author: Boo
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor tried to make the lectures more interesting by including different videos. He tried to make the lessons more interactive, so he asked a lot of questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation is important as I remember it weighs around 10% to 15%
Try to answer more questions in class
, then you will be able to get a better grade.
The format of the two mid term exams and final were similar. Both MC and short questions are included. As long as you have attended the lectures and reviewed the notes briefly, you would be able to finish it. Although I didnâ€™t get a decent grade at last, but I will say the effort I paid is equivalent to the grade. So just work hard and this could be a good grade course for you.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly readings.
Some are optional.
No homework
The workload is light, just go to class!

reviews.author: LLLEE
reviews.comment_content:
The professor cannot finish all the content in the tentative schedule, hence some readings on the list are optional.

PART ONE:  SOCIAL CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT
-What explains the â€œHong Kong Economic Miracle?â€
Technology and Capital
-Neo-Confucianism(å®‹æ˜ç†å­¸)and the Asian Values Debate.
-Hong Kong and the Modern World System.
-Hong Kongâ€™s Industrial Experience. What was it like for ordinary people?
-The transformation of traditional Chinese beliefs: Why do we love ghost stories?
-Social Solidarity (ç¤¾æœƒåœ˜çµ) and Suicide: Are we becoming more isolated?

PART TWO. SOCIAL AND POLITICAL INEQUALITIES
-The â€œminimally integratedâ€ political system
-Where did the democracy movement come from?
-Who are the poor? Hong Kongâ€™s â€œNew Poorâ€ The governmentâ€™s response to poverty in Hong Kong. Has minimum wage legislation worked?
-Class Analysis in Hong Kong
-The power elite
-How Equal are men and women in Hong Kong? The Facts of  Gender Inequality    
-Gender, Socialization, language and the media.
-Gender inequality in the workplace
-Why donâ€™t more men stay home to look after children? Understanding Gender inequality in the home
-Discrimination and sexual orientation (**Guest Lecture)
-Migrants and ethnic minorities in Hong Kong. The South Asian Experience

PART THREE. IDENTITY, INTIMACY AND FAMILY
-Who am I? The rise of the â€œHeunggongyahnâ€  (é¦™æ¸¯äºº)
-Why so many lonely hearts? The search for intimacy
-The Changing Hong Kong Family. Understanding Marriage and Divorce in Hong Kong
-Development of youth culture
reviews.comment_teaching:
-Professor is funny, casual and generous. You don't need to prepare your "brain" before coming to the class. Very relax and pressure-free.
-Interesting discussion for the topics of poverty, suicide, and the HK-China relationship.
-Fragmented PowerPoint, need to organize what has been discussed after class, otherwise kind of messy.
reviews.comment_grading:
I have got an A- for ~83%'s total course % (by estimation)

Attendance 5%: 5/5
Participation 5%: unknown, maybe 3-4/5 (answered 11-12 times in class)
Midterm 1 25%: 23/27 (Mean: 19.8   High: 27   Low: 7)
Midterm 2 25%: 29/33 (Mean: 24.73    High: 33 Low: 0)
Final Exam 40%: 25.5/31 (Mean: 23.34 High: 31 Low: 8)

-Exams are typically easy, except for the short answered questions which I have never received a full mark
reviews.comment_workload:
Things to do to secure a good grade:
-Attendance with the camera on
-Raise hands and answer open-ended questions
-Readings: 1-2 passages per week (will be tested)
-Review documentaries played during lectures (the professor will play half of the content during lectures and urge you to finish them after class)
-markdown some notes when listening

reviews.author: Yayx14
reviews.title: Not very Good grade
reviews.comment_content:
same as before
Part 1: Social Change and Development
Part 2: Social and Political Inequalities
Part 3: Identity, Intimacy and Family
reviews.comment_teaching:
you will get many chances to answer questions.
He encourage us to exchange ideas.
reviews.comment_grading:
1st MidTerm: 18/27 (25%) (Mean: 19.74/27 SD:4.69)
2nd MidTerm: 29/33 (25%) (Mean: 24.76/33 SD: 5.01)
Final: 24.5/31 (40%)  (Mean: 23.34/31 SD: 5.29)
Attendance (with cameras on) 5/5 (5%)
Participation 0/5 (5%)
I have never answer questions in class but have got full marks in attendance
So my total marks shd be about 75.2/100
I've got B.
reviews.comment_workload: no homework. But you need to read some articles before lesson. (in case you want to answer question)

reviews.author: Humphrey
reviews.comment_content: The content is easy. It talks about old Hong Kong and some cultural values.
reviews.comment_teaching: Groves is very funny. Though maybe the content is a little bit boring, he often talks in an interesting way. He also asks a lot of easy questions, make sure you often answer the questions to let him remember your name. One minor poor thing, turning on the cam is a must.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is quite ok. The average score is quite high. However, the questions are common sense. You could just memorize some of the keywords to at least get a B+. For A, you may drop more notes during lesson.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very low. There are just two quizzes. No homework. So no need constant study. Just study before two days of the exam. No worries!

reviews.author: ychb
reviews.comment_content: Stuff about HK society
reviews.comment_teaching: Groves is a guy who is able to grasp the way of making students being attentive to his class, he is a funny guy. He tries to make the course as interesting as he can.
reviews.comment_grading: Not really good, the course is not as good grade as ppl think. There are too many senior ppl who will beat the sh*t out of you in the exams, some even are Groves' students in other courses taught by him. I only got a B- even my midterm is above mean by more than half an SD and just slightly below mean in the final (Grade policy: 40% midterm & 60% final, there is extra credits but not compulsory)
reviews.comment_workload: Only memorizing slides and reading materials for the exam, which may be difficult since there are a ton of them.

reviews.author: lzha97
reviews.comment_content: very straightforward and quite interesting. Some of the content is a bit outdated (from pre-2010) but most of it is pretty relevant to contemporary Hong Kong. He also uses a lot of information from other sosc courses which he teaches, like education.
reviews.comment_teaching: professor groves mostly just reads off of the lecture slides. sometimes he conducts survey in class to prove a point about something in lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: it is easy to get an A on the final and midterm if you just read over the lecture slides before the exams. There are readings as well but the concept is reinforced in lectures. If you go to all of the lectures and do the readings, you probably don't even have to study for the exams to pass
reviews.comment_workload:
midterm, 40 %, final 60 % + extra credit volunteer project

the readings are usually pretty short and sparse. occasionally a reading will be longer and more in - depth. May be difficult for students with non-English background, but cantonese TA is very helpful.

There is no homework so the course is one of the lightest workloads possible.

reviews.author: Kunal1999
reviews.comment_content: Covers a variety of topics regarding HK. "A sociologically informed examination of Hong Kong society. Topics include social change, political, economic and gender inequalities, the rise of the democracy movement, discrimination, consumer culture, identity, intimacy, and family life."
reviews.comment_teaching: Hard to concentrate in lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very tough!

Midterm: 40%, Final: 60%
Bonus: Volunteer Work: 7%, In-class participation: 3%
reviews.comment_workload: Very heavy. Exam included readings and powerpoint. If you attend almost every lecture, then information will slowly settle in and you will find it easy to revise. But, if you constantly miss lessons, then it is very tough to keep up to date!!! So you better try to stay up to date :)

reviews.author: echoes
reviews.title: New Perspectives
reviews.comment_content: An upgrade version of DSE L.S. that focuses less on the cause and effect but more on motives and actions of individuals being just a tiny part of how society works. We talked about politics, cultures, gender. Best if you're already good with L.S. or like to watch news stories. Interesting course for exchange students if you want to learn more about HK. Shame he can't finish all topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Groves' sound is nice to listen to, won't send you to sleep. Tell interesting stories and taught me a new perspective, good job in introducing sociology.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade you on Midterm, Final and Class Participation.  Exam format is MC + 2-3 long questions. Easy to manage if you paid attention in class. Would actually ask you something the prof said.
reviews.comment_workload: I didn't do any voluntary work. Took notes in class but most main points can be gathered from the PowerPoints. Answered questions every other class.

reviews.author: Ivy123
reviews.comment_content: An introductory course covering almost everything about Hong Kong. Should not be hard if you are a local and pay attention to what happens around you
reviews.comment_teaching: All electronic devices are not allowed. Lectures could be pretty boring as professional can dwell on one topic for very long time
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty easy to get a good grade. As long as you read all the readings and the powerpoints. Lectures are not that important. Extra credits are given for participating in voluntary works.
reviews.comment_workload: Mid-term and final only. Workload is almost non-existent if you choose not to participate in voluntary works.

reviews.author: NicNicole
reviews.comment_content: The content is very interesting that you could learn many things that you will never notice. For example, Prof. Groves taught us something about the Hong Kong sex industry and gave us the chance to talk to a related non-profit organization. It is a great opportunity to learn out of the campus.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Groves is a very humorous professor that he taught us in a funny way. Although his voice is a little bit soft that sometimes make me feel sleepy, his lessons are not boring as he included different teaching materials/methods such as videos, discussions or others.
reviews.comment_grading: Actually, the grade is not very nice but not very harsh. If you finished the readings that he gave, you could get B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Professor will announce the required readings for next lesson, nearly every lesson. Some of them are short articles but most of them are chapters of a book, about 20 pages. Words are difficult for me but the contents are interesting most of the time.

Also, the professor will not take attendance but he will give some extra mark to active students. And, some of the content he talked in class will not upload to the canvas so attendance is important.

reviews.author: Andyle_e
reviews.title: Recommend
reviews.comment_content: Basically introduction of past and present Hong Kong with different sociological themes.
reviews.comment_teaching: This professor taught this course by pure online mode and face-to-face quizes. The videos made by the professor are concise which saved me lots of time when studying.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair as long as you follow all the guidelines. As a common core, the mean would be high. You are allowed to skip one quiz out of a total of 5 quizes.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the course is light that makes it feel like less than 3 credits. Would be fine by reading all the videos and required readings.

There is also one group project which is about making a short video and the overall workload is fine.

reviews.author: Hailey0612
reviews.title: Competitive but fun
reviews.comment_content:
PART ONE:  SOCIAL CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT
PART TWO. SOCIAL AND POLITICAL INEQUALITIES
PART THREE. IDENTITY, INTIMACY AND FAMILY
reviews.comment_teaching:
Grovesâ€™s teaching is nice.
My semesterâ€™s lecture is delivered in self-pace online. He will upload approximately 3-6 videos every week. His accent is really nice. You can understand easily what he is saying.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very competitive
There are 5 quizzes in total
The mean of every quizzes is extremely high, nearly 80-85%
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite low workload for quizzes. There are 5 quizzes in total and the contents are not cumulative. Therefore, the workload is not that heavy.
However, there is a project which requires 4-5 people to finish it. It you meet a nice group mate. It will probably be fine. However, the projectâ€™s workload is quite heavy.
Also, it is very necessarily to read all Grovesâ€™s reading since it will appear a lot of questions in the quizzes. He claimed that it is a small amount of writing. However, in fact it is quite a lot. He normally assigns reading or extra videos every week.

reviews.author: hokjarh
reviews.comment_content:
PART 1:  Social Change & Development
PART 2. Social & Political Inequalities
PART 3. Identity, Intimacy & Family
reviews.comment_teaching: Passionated. Offers short break each lesson. Always ask questions (to give participation marks). Prof releases lecture notes after lessons. Interactive activities are included (in-class discussion, mentimeter, etc.).Might invite guest speakers to share his/her experience on related topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Participation & attendance
25% Midterm 1
25% Midterm 2
40% Final exam

The final exam is cumulative.
Readings are included in the exam syllabus but the content focus on lecture notes and in-class discussions. Didn't read any of the readings and got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
2 midterms
1 final
participation & attendance required
readings

reviews.author: briancng
reviews.comment_content: You learn about Hong Kong and how it was able to industrialize so quickly, and many of the issues facing it today. Interesting if you have an interest in how Hong Kong got to be the way it is today.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is British and engaging. Tries to make things interesting by engaging students.
reviews.comment_grading: Class completely graded by exams. One midterm (40%) and one final (60%). Mostly MC with some free response.
reviews.comment_workload: Previous reviews complained of long readings but I think it's manageable. He seems to have tried to make it lighter but still about an hour per assignment.

reviews.author: Jasmin
reviews.comment_content:
PART ONE: SOCIAL CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT
PART TWO: SOCIAL AND POLITICAL INEQUALITIES
PART THREE: IDENTITY, CONSUMERISM AND FAMILY
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is engaging, and allows active student participation. The professor does not allow electronics in class and will not post lecture notes before class, so you will have to jot down a lot of notes in class.
reviews.comment_grading: I got 1.5 SD above mean in both midterm and final, and got 6/7 for the voluntary project. My final grade was an A.
reviews.comment_workload: There's only a midterm (40%), final (60%) and a voluntary project (additional 7% if you get full marks on the project). It's easy to score 1 SD bove mean if you attend class regularly and pay attention in class. You do not need to study for the midterm and final if you have paid attention in class. There is also weekly reading but you will be fine if you do the reading right before midterm and final.

reviews.author: Lock
reviews.title: æ‹‰Grade Course
